{{BLPsources|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox musical artist |name =Forever The Sickest Kids |image = FTSK Bamboozle.jpg |background = group_or_band |origin = [[Burleson, Texas|Burleson]], [[Texas]] |genre = [[Pop punk]]{{cite web|url=http://www.sputnikmusic.com/bands.php?bandid=8451 |title=Forever the Sickest Kids reviews, music, news |publisher=sputnikmusic |date=2009-11-17 |accessdate=2010-06-22}}
[[Powerpop]]{{cite web|url=http://www.last.fm/music/Forever+the+Sickest+Kids |title=Forever the Sickest Kids â Discover music, videos, concerts, stats, & pictures at |publisher=Last.fm |date=2008-11-21 |accessdate=2010-06-22}}
|label = [[Universal Motown Records]] (2006-2011) |website = [http://www.foreverthesickestkids.com foreverthesickestkids.com] |current_members = Jonathan Cook
Austin Bello
Kyle Burns
Caleb Turman
|past_members = Kent Garrison
Marc Stewart | associated_acts =
Been Bradley
The Flipside
Selena Gomez
}} '''Forever the Sickest Kids''' is an American pop punk band from [[Dallas, Texas]], who have yet to be signed to a new label after the closure of [[Universal Motown Records]]. In issue 228 of ''[[Alternative Press (music magazine)|Alternative Press]]'', the group was named the number one underground band in the "22 Best Underground Bands". Their first EP, ''[[Television Off, Party On (EP)|Television Off, Party On]]'', was released on July 3, 2007. Their debut album, ''[[Underdog Alma Mater]]'', was later released on April 29, 2008. The first part of their new three-part [[mini-LP]] (a collection entitled 3P), ''[[The Weekend: Friday]]'', was released on November 17, 2009, with their newest, self-titled album released on March 1, 2011. ==History== ===Formation and ''Underdog Alma Mater'' (2006-2008)=== While browsing [[PureVolume]], lead singer Jonathan Cook accidentally spent $350 that the band did not have to receive a front page placement of a song that they also did not have. For this reason, they went into the studio and wrote "Hey Brittany", then recorded it with their producer Geoff Rockwell in a matter of days. Since it was first posted, "Hey Brittany" has garnered many Internet plays and triggered a bidding war among eight record labels.{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}} On April 24, 2007, Universal Motown emerged victorious, and released the band's ''[[Television Off, Party On (EP)|Television Off, Party On]]'' EP on July 3. The releases of ''[[The Sickest Warped Tour EP]]'' and the ''[[Hot Party Josh]'' would soon follow.{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}} The band's first single, "[[Whoa Oh! (Me vs. Everyone)]]", was released on April 20, 2008. Their debut album ''[[Underdog Alma Mater]]'' was later released on April 29, and their second single, "[[She's a Lady (FTSK song)|She's a Lady]]" was released on July 14. Along with the musical acts [[Matches]] and [[Sonny (band)|Sonny]], The band supported [[All Time Low]] and [[The Rocket Summer]] on the 2008 [[Alternative Press (music magazine)|Alternative Press]] tour from March 14 to May 2. The band played with [[Metro Station (band)|Metro Station]], [[The Cab]], [[Danger Radio]] and [[The Maine (band)|The Maine]] on their first headlining tour, and later performed on the [[Warped Tour 2008|2008 Vans Warped Tour]]. They appeared on ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'' on June 12, performing their single "Whoa Oh! (Me vs. Everyone)". The band then headed to [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]] to perform at the annual Summer Sonic Festival. In late September, the band undertook a brief headlining tour in the UK, after [[Cobra Starship]], the original headliners, post-poned their tour. The band also held the Sassy Back tour throughout October and November with Cobra Starship, [[Hit the Lights]], and [[Sing it Loud]]. ===''Underdog Alma Mater Deluxe Edition'' (2009)=== In June 2008, it was decided that the band's debut studio album, ''Underdog Alma Mater'', would be re-released as a [[Special edition|deluxe edition]] on July 7, 2009. This deluxe release features the original songs, plus 17 previously unreleased tracks, including demos and acoustic songs. On April 26, 2009, members of Forever the Sickest Kids, [[We the Kings]], [[The Tattle-Tales]], and several other people were injured in an incident with the Philadelphia Police Department at the [[The TLA|Theatre of the Living Arts]], a venue the bands played at on the Bamboozle Road Tour. Travis Clark of We the Kings said, "Philadelphia cops just beat us up for nothing!"[http://www.altpress.com/news/6635.htm Forever the Sickest Kids and We the Kings involved in beating by Philly police] The band also played at the [[Warped Tour 2009|2009 Vans Warped Tour]] from July 22 to August 26. ===''The Weekend: Friday'' (2009)=== On November 17, 2009, the band released the first of what would have been three mini-LPs (a collection entitled 3P) called ''[[The Weekend: Friday]]''. The other two parts of the 3P, ''The Weekend: Saturday'' and ''The Weekend: Sunday'', were set to be released in the Fall 2010/Summer 2011. The first single from ''The Weekend: Friday'' was "What Do You Want From Me?". The music video was released that month. Forever The Sickest Kids along with [[We The Kings]] supported [[You Me At Six]] on their sold out U.K. tour that started on March 9, 2010 to the 20th. The video to "She Likes (Bittersweet Love)" has two prequel videos that tell the story building up to the premiere of the music video, this was the UK's [[Kerrang!]] video of the week the week of April 19, 2010. The boys supported [[The Downtown Fiction]], [[All Time Low]], [[Boys Like Girls]], [[Third Eye Blind]], and [[LMFAO (group)|LMFAO]] on The Bamboozle Roadshow 2010. Along with numerous other supporting acts, including [[3OH!3]], [[Good Charlotte]], [[Cartel (band)|Cartel]], and [[Simple Plan]]. ===''Forever the Sickest Kids'' (2010-present)=== A single from the upcoming album was released on [[YouTube]] on June 5, 2010. It is called ''Keep on Bringing Me Down''. Another song leaked, entitled "Get Over Yourself", on YouTube as well. Forever the Sickest Kids just recently{{when|date=July 2011}} ended "The Summer Camp for the Dope Awesome Kids Tour" which featured [[The Scene Aesthetic]], [[The Ready Set]], [[A Cursive Memory]] and Phone Calls from Home. During October 2010, Forever the Sickest Kids supported [[Bowling for Soup]] on their UK and Ireland tour, along with [[A (Band)|A]] and [[The Dollyrots]]. On November 25, Jonathan Cook revealed through his newly created [[Tumblr]] account that they would not be releasing the new mini-LP ''The Weekend: Saturday'' in the foreseeable future. Instead they would be releasing a self-titled album. The band explained their decision with this statement on their [[Tumblr]] "We went into the studio with David Bendeth to record 5 songs for our next release of ''The Weekend: Friday'', but whilst we were in the process of pre-production and tracking our band came to an all-inclusive decision that we wanted to record 5-6 more songs and go all out and create another full length album." Cook did not mention anything about the future of The Weekend series. While on the Christmas Pageant Tour with Family Force 5 in December 2010, Jonathan Cook announced that their self-titled album will be released on March 1, 2011. Also while on the Christmas Pageant Tour, the band began to play a new song from the self-titled album called Life of the Party. The band was on Stickam on November 8, 2010, and they leaked a new song "I Guess You Can Say Things Are Getting Pretty Serious" from the album. On January 10, 2011 Kent Garrison posted on his blog that he was leaving the band.http://www.kentallengarrison.com/post/2691979150/future On February 11, the band released a teaser videohttp://commonrevolt.com/post/3237579919 for the new album featuring the band performing a new song with no vocal tracks heard. On February 15, a new song entitled "Forever Girl" was released.http://commonrevolt.com/post/3304987591 The album was released on March 1. In April 2011, Forever The Sickest Kids set out on the headlining "Spring Break Your Heart" tour with [[Breathe Carolina]], [[We Are the In Crowd]], [[This Century]], [[Tonight Alive]] and [[Before Their Eyes]]. During the summer of 2011, Forever The Sickest Kids played a series of mall tours including the Zumiez Couch Tour and Simon dTOUR Live. On September 22,2011 Marc Stewart confirmed on Twitter that he was leaving the band. In February and March 2012, Forever The Sickest Kids will be set to perform at the Australian music festival Soundwave alongside Madina Lake, Trivium and CKY. The Bands Self-Titled album has now sold over 125,000 copies in the US alone, placing them in the top 30 rock albums of 2011. The Band has been rumored to have been in negotiations with Warner Brothers Records, Sony Music Group, EMI, and Redbull. FTSK released a new single entitled "Shut the Front Door (Too Young for This)" on October 28, 2011. ==Band Members== Jonathan Cook- [[Lead Vocals]] Caleb Turman- [[Lead Guitar]], [[Vocals]] Austin Bello- [[Bass Guitar]], [[Vocals]] Kyle Burns- [[Drums]], [[Percussion]] ==Discography== ===Studio albums=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Year ! rowspan="2"| Album details ! colspan="3"| Peak chart positions |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! style="width:35px;"| [[Billboard 200|US]]

(Me vs. Everyone)]]" | 38 | 1 | style="text-align:left;" rowspan="2"| ''Underdog Alma Mater'' |- | style="text-align:left;"| "[[She's a Lady (Forever the Sickest Kids song)|She's a Lady]]" | 21 | 9 |- | rowspan="3"| 2010 | style="text-align:left;"| "[[What Do You Want from Me (Forever the Sickest Kids song)|What Do You Want from Me]]" | â | â | style="text-align:left;" rowspan="2"| ''The Weekend: Friday'' |- | style="text-align:left;"| "She Likes (Bittersweet Love)" | â | â |- | style="text-align:left;"| "Keep on Bringing Me Down" | â | â | style="text-align:left;" rowspan="3"| ''Forever the Sickest Kids'' |- | rowspan="3"| 2011 | style="text-align:left;"| "Crossroads (I Guess You Can Say Things Are Getting Pretty Serious)" | â | â |- | style="text-align:left;"| "Summer Song" | â | â |- | 2011 style="text-align:left;"| "Shut the Front Door (Too Young for This)" | â | â | style="text-align:left;" | Non Released Album "The Weekend: Saturday". |- | colspan="10" style="font-size:8pt"| "â" denotes releases that did not chart |- |} ===Compilations=== *''[[Punk Goes Crunk]]'': Contributed "[[Men in Black (song)|Men in Black]]", originally by [[Will Smith]] *''[[Punk Goes Classic Rock]]'': Contributed "[[Crazy Train]]", originally by [[Ozzy Osbourne]] ===Guest appearances=== * 2006 - "Lucky Girl" by The Tattle-Tales (ft. Forever the Sickest Kids) * 2009 - "Jumping (Out the Window) (The Remix) [Guitar Down Version]" by [[Ron Browz]] (ft. Forever the Sickest Kids) * 2010 - "Um Lance, NÃ£o Um Romance" by Cine (ft. Forever the Sickest Kids) ==Other media== "[[Whoa Oh! (Me vs. Everyone)]]" was featured in commercials for various [[Nerf]] products. Also in newer [[Nerf]] commercials their new single "[[Keep on Bringing Me Down]]" is used. A second version of the song "[[Whoa Oh! (Me vs. Everyone)]]" was later released featuring [[Selena Gomez]]. Forever the Sickest Kids also aided in putting together her album, ''[[Kiss & Tell (Selena Gomez & the Scene album)|Kiss & Tell]]''. The band was also featured on an episode of [[Silent Library (MTV series)|Silent Library]] "What Do You Want from Me" was used in the end credits of ''[[Diary of a Wimpy Kid (film)|Diary of a Wimpy Kid]]'', was also featured in commercials for various [[Nerf]] products, and was released a single on [[iTunes]] as "What Do You Want from Me (Diary of a Wimpy Kid Mix)". More recently{{when|date=July 2011}}, the song "Good Life" from their latest album was used in the newest [[Nerf]] and [[Super Soaker]] commercials. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.foreverthesickestkids.com}} {{Forever the Sickest Kids}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Forever The Sickest Kids}} [[Category:American power pop groups]] [[Category:Electronica music groups]] [[Category:Musical groups from Dallas, Texas]] [[Category:Musical sextets]] [[de:Forever the Sickest Kids]] [[id:Forever the Sickest Kids]] [[it:Forever the Sickest Kids]] [[ms:Forever the Sickest Kids]] [[ja:ãã©ã¼ã¨ã´ã¡ã¼ã»ã¶ã»ã·ãã±ã¹ãã»ã­ããº]] [[pt:Forever the Sickest Kids]]
